(h)  In addition to the foregoing, all adult establishments shall comply with provisions of the Town of Kernersville Zoning Ordinance relative to adult uses. Further, nothing in this Chapter is intended to authorize any use or operation in violation of the Town of Kernersville Zoning Ordinance. 
(i)  The hours of operation shall be between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. 
(j)  The sale, use or consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises of an adult establishment as defined herein is prohibited. 
(k)  There shall be ten-foot separations between the live entertainers and patrons. Workers in adult establishments who are not entertaining shall not be in a state of nudity or semi-nudity. Workers in adult establishments who are entertaining shall neither appear in a state of nudity nor engage in specified sexual activities. 
(Ord. No. O-2003-22, §§ 1, 2, 7-1, 2003) 
Sec. 5-108. - Inspections. 
    The applicant and/or permittee shall permit representatives of the Town Manager, Town Police Department, Fire Marshall, Building Inspector, Community Development Department or any other state or county agency or town department or agency to inspect the portions of the adult establishment that are open to the public, during business hours, for the purpose of insuring compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. O-2003-22, §§ 1, 2, 7-1, 2003) 
Sec. 5-109. - Fees. 
    The non-refundable initial application fee for an adult establishment permit is one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). This fee is based on the cost of the administration and enforcement of this chapter including the cost of the Town Manager, Town Police Department, Fire Marshall, Building Inspector and Community Development Department reviews and inspections. The annual renewal fee for an adult establishment permit shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. O-2003-22, §§ 1, 2, 7-1, 2003) 
Sec. 5-110. - Term of permit 
(a)  Each permit shall expire one (1) year from the date of issuance and may be renewed only by making application as provided for in section 5-105. Application for renewal must be made at least thirty (30) days before the expiration date. If the application for renewal is made less than thirty (30) days before the expiration date, the application shall be treated as a new application. Provided, however, that during the pendency of the application, whether treated as a renewal or new application, and during any timely appeal before the Town Manager, the permittee shall be allowed to continue operation of the adult establishment. 
(b)  In the event the Community Development Director denies renewal of a permit, the applicant shall be entitled to an appeals procedure as set forth in section 5-106(e). Provided, however, that during the pendency of any timely appeal before the Town Manager, the permittee shall be allowed to continue operation of the adult establishment. If the Community Development Director's denial of permit renewal is upheld, or if not timely appealed by the applicant, the applicant shall not be issued a permit for one (1) year from the date of the said denial. If subsequent to denial the Community Development Director finds that the basis for the denial of the renewal permit has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a permit by the Community Development Director, and the Community Development Director shall have the discretion to deem the grant of the permit as a new permit or a renewal permit. 
(Ord. No. O-2003-22, §§ 1, 2, 7-1, 2003) 
Sec. 5-111. - Suspension of permit. 
(a)  The Community Development Director shall suspend a license for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days if it is determined that a licensee or an employee of a licensee has: 
(1)  Violated or is not in compliance with any section of this ordinance; 
(2)  Refused to allow an inspection of the sexually oriented business premises as authorized by this chapter. 
(b)  Upon suspension of a permit by the Community Development Director, the permittee may appeal the same in accordance with the provisions of Sec. 5-106(e) of this chapter. Provided, however, that during the pendency of any timely appeal before the Town Manager, the permittee shall be allowed to continue operation of the adult establishment. 
(Ord. No. O-2003-22, §§ 1, 2, 7-1, 2003) 
Sec. 5-112. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)  The Community Development Director shall revoke a permit if a cause of suspension in section 5-111 occurs and the permit has been suspended previously within the preceding twelve (12) months. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of section 5-111 relative to grounds for suspension of permits, the Community Development Director shall revoke a permit if they determine that: 
(1)  A permittee gave false or misleading information in the material submitted during the application process. 
(2)  A permittee has knowingly allowed possession, use or sale of controlled substances on the premises. 
(3)  A permittee has knowingly allowed prostitution on the premises. 
(4)  A permittee has knowingly operated the adult establishment during a period of time when the permittee's permit was suspended. 
(5)  A permittee has knowingly allowed any act of sexual conduct to occur in or on the premises of the adult establishment. 
(6)  A permittee is delinquent in payment to the town or state of any taxes, fees or fines in relation to the adult establishment. 
(7)  A permittee has knowingly allowed a person under the age of eighteen (18) years to enter the premises of the adult establishment. For purposes of this subsection (b)(7), a permittee shall be presumed to have known the age of an person under the age of eighteen (18) years who enters the premises of the adult establishment unless the attendant or other employee and/or agent of the permittee requested and received identification of such entrant and reasonably relied upon such identification. 
(8)  There was a change of owner or operator for which a transfer application was not timely filed. 
(9)  The permittee has been convicted, during the duration of the permit period, of any crime involving sexual misconduct (including but not limited to N.C. Gen. Stat. §§ 14-177 through 14-202.1 (Chapter 14, Article 26-Offenses Against Public Morality), N.C. Gen. Stat. §§ 14-203 through 14-208 (Chapter 14, Article 27-Prostitution), or of any federal statute relating to prostitution or for any violation of any law or ordinance of any governmental unit concerning or related to adult-oriented business or establishments or the business or profession of massage. 
(c)  When the Community Development Director revokes a permit, the revocation shall continue for a period of one (1) year, and the permittee shall not be issued a permit under this chapter during the period of revocation. If, subsequent to revocation but during the period of revocation, the Community Development Director finds that the basis for the revocation has been corrected or abated, the Community Development Director may, but is not required to grant a new permit. Provided, however, in the event that revocation is for any of the grounds specified in subsection (b)(9) above, such revocation shall last three (3) years from the date of the conviction upon which the revocation was based. 
(d)  Upon revocation of a permit by the Community Development Director, the permittee may appeal the same in accordance with the provisions of section 5-106(e). Provided, however, that during the pendency of any timely appeal before the Town Manager, the permittee shall be allowed to continue operation of the adult establishment. 
(Ord. No. O-2003-22, §§ 1, 2, 7-1, 2003) 
Sec. 5-113. - Location of sexually oriented businesses. 
(a)  A person commits a misdemeanor if that person operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business in any zoning district other than Limited Industrial and General Industrial, as defined and described in Town of Kernersville, Unified Development Ordinance, Chapter A-Definitions Ordinance, Adult Establishments; Chapter B, Article II-Zoning Ordinance, 2-4.6 Other Development Requirements of the Zoning Ordinance, Table 2.6 Permitted Uses; Chapter B Zoning Ordinance Article II-Zoning Districts, Official Zoning Maps, and Uses, Section 2-5.4 Adult Establishment. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if the person operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business within one hundred (100) feet of licensed premises, licensed pursuant to the alcoholic beverage control regulations of the state or one thousand (1,000) feet of: 
(1)  A church, synagogue, mosque, temple or building which is used primarily for religious worship and related religious activities; 
(2)  A public or private educational facility including but not limited to child day care facilities, nursery schools, preschools, kindergartens, elementary schools, private schools, intermediate schools, junior high schools, middle schools, high schools, vocational schools, secondary schools, continuation schools, special education schools, junior colleges, and universities; school includes the school grounds, but does not include facilities used primarily for another purpose and only incidentally as a school; 
(3)  A boundary of a residential district as defined in the Uniform Development Code for Forsyth County; 
(4)  A public park or recreational area which has been designated for park or recreational activities including but not limited to a park, playground, nature trails, swimming pool, reservoir, athletic field, basketball or tennis courts, pedestrian/bicycle paths, wilderness areas, or other similar public land within the city which is under the control, operation, or management of the city park and recreation authorities; 
(5)  The property line of a lot devoted to a residential use as defined in the Uniform Development Code for Forsyth County; 
(6)  An entertainment business which is oriented primarily towards children or family entertainment; or 
(7)  Another adult establishment. 
(c)  A person commits a misdemeanor if that person causes or permits the operation, establishment, substantial enlargement, or transfer of ownership or control of a sexually oriented business within one thousand (1,000) feet of another sexually oriented business. 
(d)  A person commits a misdemeanor if that person causes or permits the operation, establishment, or maintenance of more than one (1) sexually oriented business in the same building, structure, or portion thereof, or the increase of floor area of any sexually oriented business in any building, structure, or portion thereof containing another sexually oriented business. 
(e)  For the purpose of subsection (b) of this section, measurement shall be made in a straight line, without regard to the intervening structures or objects, from the nearest portion of the building or structure used as the part of the premises where a sexually oriented business is conducted, to the nearest property line of the premises of a use listed in subsection (b). Presence of a city, county or other political subdivision boundary shall be irrelevant for purposes of calculating and applying the distance requirements of this section. 
(f)  For purposes of subsection (c) above, the distance between any two (2) sexually oriented businesses shall be measured in a straight line, without regard to the intervening structures or objects or political boundaries, from the closest exterior wall of the structure in which each business is located. 
(g)  Any sexually oriented business lawfully operating on July 1, 2003, that is in violation of subsections (a) through (f) above shall be deemed a nonconforming use. The nonconforming use will be permitted to continue for a period not to exceed one (1) year, unless sooner terminated for any reason or voluntarily discontinued for a period of thirty (30) days or more. Such nonconforming uses shall not be increased, enlarged, extended, or altered except that the use may be changed to a conforming use. If two (2) or more sexually oriented businesses are within one thousand (1,000) feet of one another and otherwise in a permissible location, the sexually oriented business which was first established and continually operating at a particular location is the conforming use and the later established business(es) is/are nonconforming. 
(h)  A sexually oriented business lawfully operating as a conforming use is not rendered a nonconforming use by the location, subsequent to the grant or renewal of the sexually oriented business license, of a use listed in subsection b of this section within one thousand (1,000) feet of the sexually oriented business. This provision applies only to the renewal of a valid license, and does not apply when an application for a license is submitted after a license has expired or been revoked. 
(Ord. No. O-2003-22, §§ 1, 2, 7-1, 2003) 
Sec. 5-114. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  The violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor as provided in North Carolina General Statutes Section 14-4, and subject the permittee to all criminal punishments as provided by the laws of North Carolina, including but not limited to a fine not exceeding five-hundred dollars ($500.00). It is the express intent of this ordinance that the maximum fine for violation of this chapter shall exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) 
(b)  In addition to criminal penalties as set forth in subsection (a) of this section, the town may seek enforcement of this chapter through any and all remedies as provided in North Carolina General Statutes Section 160A-175 and all amendments thereto. 
(c)  A person who operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business without a valid license or in violation of this article is subject to civil penalties as well as prosecution for criminal violations. Such violations shall be punishable by a civil penalty of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per offense. 
(d)  The remedies provided in this section are not exclusive and may be sought by the town for the same acts to the extent allowed by applicable law. The remedies provided in this section are intended to be in addition to, and not in lieu, of the provisions of this chapter relative to revocation and suspension of permits to the extent allowed by applicable law. Further, it shall not constitute a defense to any injunctive or other equitable action that a remedy at law may exist. 
(e)  Each continuing day of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. O-2003-22, §§ 1, 2, 7-1, 2003) 
Sec. 5-115. - Miscellaneous provisions. 
(a)  If any section, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this chapter is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions thereof. 
(b)  All ordinances and provisions inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter are hereby repealed. All other ordinances and provisions not inconsistent with this chapter are intended to have full force and effect. 
(c)  This chapter shall become effective upon adoption by the Board of Aldermen. 
(Ord. No. O-2003-22, §§ 1, 2, 7-1, 2003) 
Chapter 6 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2010-05, § 2, adopted January 5, 2010, amended ch. 6, §§ 6-1-6-6, to read as set out herein. Prior to its adoption ch. 6 pertained to similar subject matter and was derived from Code 1980, §§ 3-3001(a)-(e); Ord. No. O-2003-09, adopted May 6, 2003 and Ord. No. O-2005-09, §§ 1-3, adopted February 1, 2005. 
Charter reference- Mayor and mayor pro tem, § 6. 
Cross reference- Offenses, Ch. 11; parades, pickets and group demonstrations, Ch. 12; streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 16. 

Sec. 6-1. - State of emergency. 
    A state of emergency shall be deemed to exist whenever, during times of great public crisis, disaster, rioting, catastrophe, or similar public emergency, for any reason, municipal public safety authorities are unable to maintain public order or afford adequate protection for lives, safety or property. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-05, § 2, 1-5-2010) 
Sec. 6-2. - Proclamation; curfew authorized. 
(a)  If an existing or threatened state of emergency endangers the lives, safety, health and welfare of the people within the Town, or threatens damage to or destruction of property, the mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to issue a public proclamation declaring to all persons the existence of such a state of emergency, and, in order to more effectively protect the lives, safety and property of people within the town, to define and impose a curfew applicable to all persons within the jurisdiction of the town. 
(b)  A meeting of the Board of Aldermen shall be called within twenty-four (24) hours after a state of emergency has been proclaimed by the Mayor. 
(c)  The Mayor is further authorized to proclaim any other restrictions or controls not specifically enumerated in this chapter as may be reasonably necessary to maintain order and protect lives or property. 
(d)  Any proclamation may be extended, altered, or repealed during the continued or threatened existence of a state of emergency by the issuance of a subsequent proclamation. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-05, § 2, 1-5-2010) 
Sec. 6-3. - Termination. 
    The Mayor shall proclaim the end of such state of emergency and curfew as soon as circumstances warrant or when directed to do so by the Board of Aldermen. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-05, § 2, 1-5-2010) 
Sec. 6-4. - Curfew-Generally. 
    The Mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to limit the application of a curfew to any area specifically designated and described within the corporate limits of the Town and to specific hours of the day or night and to exempt from the curfew police officers, firefighters, doctors, nurses, and such other classes of persons as may be essential to the preservation of public order and immediately necessary to serve the safety, health and welfare needs of the people within the Town. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-05, § 2, 1-5-2010) 
Sec. 6-5. - Same-Prohibited conduct. 
    During the existence of a proclaimed state of emergency, the Mayor may impose by proclamation restrictions providing that no person shall: 
(1)  Be or travel upon any public street, alley or roadway or upon public property, except those in search of medical assistance, food, or another commodity or service necessary to sustain the well-being of themselves or their family or some member thereof; 
(2)  Possess off one's own premises, buy, sell, give away, or otherwise transfer or dispose of any explosives, firearms, ammunition, or dangerous weapons of any kind; 
(3)  Sell beer, wines, or intoxicating beverages of any kind; or possess or consume the same off one's own premises; 
(4)  Sell gasoline or any other similar petroleum products; or any other flammable or combustible substances, except as expressly authorized by the provisions of the curfew imposed; 
(5)  Organize or conduct any demonstration, parade, march, vigil or participate therein on any of the public ways or upon any public property; 
(6)  Participate or carry on any business activity, or keep open a place of business or entertainment or any other place of public assembly; 
(7)  Access designated areas of the Town, including those areas in which a total evacuation has been ordered; 
(8)  Sell or utilize scarce supplies, including but not limited to water, electricity and other public utilities, deemed essential for the public health or safety; 
(9)  Sell goods in excess of the manufacturer's suggested retail price or at a price above the pre-emergency level, unless the merchant can document the purchase of the goods to be sold at an increased cost. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-05, § 2, 1-5-2010) 
Cross reference- Sale, possession, storage, and use of certain pyrotechnics, § 11-12. 
Sec. 6-6. - Homeland security and emergency management. 
(a)  The Kernersville Police and Fire Rescue Departments are hereby jointly designated as the Homeland Security and Emergency Management agencies for the Town. This responsibility shall include, but not be limited to, directing and coordinating plans and programs of action and response to emergencies occurring within the Town, and the response to acts of terrorism, chemical or biological hazard releases, incidents involving mass casualty and similar emergency situations. 
(b)  These departments shall be responsible for coordinating the Town response with the appropriate county, state, and federal agencies, and for evaluating and recommending adequate mutual aid agreements to help ensure that the Town receives adequate assistance from other sources should the need arise, and likewise offers its services to neighboring jurisdictions should such assistance be needed. 
(c)  Each department shall primarily focus on those aspects of Homeland Security and Emergency Management that are within its regular sphere of responsibility including not only coordination between the two (2) named departments, but also with other Town departments and other governmental entities. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-05, § 2, 1-5-2010) 
Chapter 7 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Open burning. 
(a)  Except as provided for herein this section, no person shall burn garbage or kindle or maintain any open fire, or shall knowingly furnish the materials for any such fire, or authorize any such fire to be kindled or maintained on or in any street or public ground or upon any private property within the Town. 
(b)  Exception to the preceding subsection (a) is as follows, and only under the specific circumstances, events, places, times, and conditions as are set forth herein below: 
(1)  Open burning for campfires and outdoor cooking or for human warmth and comfort is permitted without a burning permit if performed in an approved container constructed of steel, brick, or masonry. 
(2)  Clearing of farm/agricultural land. The burning of wood and vegetation is allowed only upon such property as has qualified for valuation as agricultural, horticultural or forestland by the Forsyth County Tax Supervisor's office pursuant to G.S. § 105-277.2 et seq. and only after a permit has been applied for and granted by the North Carolina Division of Forest Resources and the Forsyth County Environmental Affairs Department. 
(3)  Bonfires using clean, dry, non-treated wood are allowed by permit issued by the Fire Marshal subject to the requirements contained thereon. 
(4)  Open burning for training of fire and/or rescue personnel is allowed as permitted by the Forsyth County Environmental Affairs Department. 
(5)  The Fire Marshal shall be admitted to any burning site enumerated in this subsection (b) [or], subsection (a) above, at any time, and any person or entity who (which) starts or maintains a fire under subsection (b) above grants such consent to the Fire Marshal. Notwithstanding any permit or consent previously granted, should the Fire Marshal, at anytime, find that any burning site poses a threat to the health and/or safety of any person or structure, the Fire Marshal may order the fire extinguished immediately, at which time the person or entity responsible for such burning site shall extinguish the said burning site. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Sec. 7-2. - Interference with firefighters or fire equipment generally. 
    No person shall: 
(1)  Interfere with a firefighter in the discharge of a duty; 
(2)  Loiter about any house or other building used by the Fire Department; 
(3)  Meddle or tamper with the engine, hose or other equipment or apparatus of the Fire Department; 
(4)  Congregate in the streets or squares next to a fire so as to interfere with the Fire Department; 
(5)  Cross a fire line established at the scene of a fire by Fire Department personnel. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Cross reference- Skating within the corporate limits, § 11-14. 
Sec. 7-3. - Driving over fire hose or blocking fire-fighting equipment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive an engine, train or any motor vehicle over the fire hose or any other equipment of the Town or any other Fire Department at any time, or to block a fire-fighting apparatus or other equipment from its source of supply regardless of its distance from the fire. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Secs. 7-4-7-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE RESCUE DEPARTMENT AND CHIEF[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Fire Chief, § 17. 

Sec. 7-26. - Composition. 
    The Town's Fire Rescue Department shall consist of a Fire Rescue Chief and such other officers and firefighters, both full and part-time (volunteer), as the Town Manager may deem appropriate for the efficient operation of the Department, subject to the availability of funds as appropriated by the Board of Aldermen. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Sec. 7-27. - Chief. 
    The Town Manager shall appoint a full-time paid Chief to serve at his pleasure. This Chief will serve as Commanding Officer of all fire rescue-related personnel and, under the direction of and subject to the supervision of the Town Manager, through his approval and periodic amendments to the standard operating procedure, the Chief shall have general control over the Fire Department, including personnel, apparatus, buildings, and the fire alarm system. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Sec. 7-28. - Organization. 
    As Commanding Officer of the Fire Rescue Department the Chief, under the general direction and supervision of the Town Manager, shall organize the Department in such a manner as he deems appropriate for effective operations and to carry out his assigned duties and for issuing general rules and regulations governing the operation of the Department. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Sec. 7-29. - Inspection powers. 
    From time to time, members of the Fire Rescue Department may be detailed or empowered to inspect various locations or occupancies for fire hazards and for violation of the Fire Prevention Code. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Sec. 7-30. - Member selection. 
    The Chief shall select all members of the department, both full and part time, based on qualifications including education and training, related job experience, physical condition and other job related considerations. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Sec. 7-31. - Personnel policy. 
    All employees of the department, full and part time and volunteers, are subject to the general personnel policies of the Town as adopted from time to time by the Board of Aldermen. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Sec. 7-32. - Officer selection, term of service. 
    By methods approved by the Town Manager, the Chief shall select all officers of the Department from both the full and part time (volunteer) personnel, based on relevant qualifications. All officers shall serve until removed by the Chief or until resignation. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Sec. 7-33. - Provision of rescue services. 
    The Fire Rescue Department shall be responsible for the provision of rescue services within the corporate limits. Such services shall include, but not be limited to provision of medical first responder service and rescue service in emergency rescue situations, provision of emergency medical technician assistance, assisting with removal of persons from endangerment or entrapment, and other similar rescue activities. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Secs. 7-34-7-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CODE ENFORCEMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-51. - Code adopted; Bureau established. 
(a)  Except as hereinafter amended, the provisions of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code and the appendices thereto, current edition, adopted by the North Carolina Building Code Council are hereby adopted and made applicable as the Fire Prevention and Control Ordinance of the Town. A copy of the Code shall be on file in the office of the Fire Marshal. 
(b)  Amendments to the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code, which are adopted and published by the North Carolina State Building Code Council, shall be effective on the date prescribed by the North Carolina State Building Code Council. 
(c)  The North Carolina State Building Code volume that is titled Administration and Enforcement Requirements is hereby referenced for the administration of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code, current edition for periodic inspection of buildings altered, repaired, or rehabilitated in accordance with the existing building code. 
(d)  A bureau of fire prevention within the Fire Rescue Department and subject to the general supervision of the Fire Rescue Chief shall be responsible for the enforcement of the Codes adopted herein. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Sec. 7-52. - Fire marshal. 
    The Fire Rescue Chief shall, subject to the approval of the Town Manager, designate a person to serve as Fire Marshal. The Fire Marshal shall head the bureau of fire prevention and report directly to the Fire Rescue Chief on all matters concerning fire prevention and investigation. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Sec. 7-53. - Board of appeals. 
(a)  An owner or occupant may appeal any decision of the Fire Marshal within ten (10) calendar days of the inspection or notice of fire code violation by submitting such appeal and the reasons therefore to the Fire Rescue Chief. 
(b)  Upon receipt of an appeal under this section, the Fire Chief shall have ten (10) calendar days during which the appeal will be examined and a decision rendered. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Sec. 7-54. - Permits. 
(a)  Permits required by the Fire Code shall be obtained from the Fire Marshal or his designee and shall be kept on the premises designated therein at all times, readily available for inspection by the Fire Marshal. Permit fees shall be specified in the Town of Kernersville Schedule of Fees and Charges. 
(b)  In addition to those permits specified as mandatory in the Fire Code, the following optional permit sections are adopted as mandatory permits within the Town of Kernersville: 
Fire Code Number Subject Area 105.6.3 Aviation Facilities 105.6.5 Battery Systems 105.6.6 Cellulose Nitrate Film 105.6.8 Combustible Filters 105.6.13 Dry Cleaning Plants 105.6.31 Open burning. 105.6.33 Open Flames and Candles 105.6.41 Rooftop Heliports  
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Secs. 7-55-7-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NOTICE OF VIOLATION 

Sec. 7-66. - Issuance. 
    Employees of the Fire Rescue Department detailed to perform fire prevention duties are empowered to issue notices of Fire Code violations when such personnel have reasonable cause to believe that any person has violated any provision of the Fire Code or failed to correct specified violations from a previous inspection. If the violation presents an imminent danger to life, the notice of the Fire Code violation shall be issued immediately. The notice of violation shall be in writing, signed by the Fire Marshal and/or the fire official charged with the enforcement of the Fire Code, and shall be delivered or mailed to the offender either at the residence or the place of business or at the place where the violation occurred. Each day's continuing violation shall be a separate and distinct offense. Pursuant to North Carolina General Statutes 160A-175(b) and 14-4, violation of any provision of the Fire Code shall not constitute a misdemeanor or infraction. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Sec. 7-67. - Contents. 
    The notice of violation shall specify the civil penalty imposed upon the violator and shall direct the violator to appear before a specific person within fifteen (15) days to pay the penalty or alternatively to pay the penalty by mail. The penalty imposed shall be as set from time to time by the Board of Aldermen and kept on file by the Town Clerk for violations of the Life Safety Code sections or some lesser sum for violation of the Fire Code or of another provision of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Sec. 7-68. - Time for correction. 
    The notice of Fire Code violation shall specify a time period during which the violation must be corrected. This specified time shall be seven (7) calendar days unless otherwise set forth in the notice. If the violation is not corrected within the specified time, the violator shall be subject to issuance of notice of violation as for a new and separate offense. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Sec. 7-69. - Civil penalty; delinquency. 
    If the Fire Code violator does not pay the required civil penalty within fifteen (15) days after issuance of the notice of violation, a delinquency charge of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be added to the amount specified in the notice of violation and notice of the delinquency charge shall be mailed to the violator. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Secs. 7-70-7-85. - Reserved.

ARTICLE V. - EMERGENCY ACCESS TO GATED PROPERTIES AND DEVELOPMENTS 

Sec. 7-101. - Permit required. 
    Prior to the installation of any gate or other device that will obstruct the access of emergency vehicles or emergency personnel, to commercial, residential areas, or open space/undeveloped areas, plans and specifications shall be submitted to the Town Fire Rescue Department, Community Development Department, and Police Department for permit issuance and plan approval. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Sec. 7-102. - Access requirements. 
(a)  All vehicular access ways through a gated entrance or exit shall be required to provide not less than fourteen (14) feet of overhead clearance and fourteen (14) feet of horizontal clearance. 
(b)  All gates shall open in a manner to ensure that the opening clearance required herein is fully available and is not in any way obstructed by the gate. 
(c)  The following gate design standards and guidelines shall be required: 
(1)  All gated community developments, commercial and residential properties shall have gates that are electrical in operation. All electrical vehicular gates shall be provided with access control using a radio transceiver for public safety and authorized users. This transceiver will allow emergency vehicles to open the gate from a mobile or portable radio and shall be as required by the Fire Rescue Department to ensure conformity and ease of operation during emergency response. 
(2)  A lock box shall be installed to allow emergency personnel access through pedestrian gates. Emergency personnel must be able to access manual backup controls. 
(3)  All electrical vehicular gates must be provided with a fail-open device to open it during power failures. These devices shall restore the gate(s) to the closed position after the power is restored. 
(4)  If a gate is secured with a chain and lock, the Town shall not be held liable for repairs to such chain or lock necessitated by emergency entrance onto the property. Usage of a chain and lock shall only be permitted on commercial or industrial properties when there are no employees or members of the public within the fenced area. 
(5)  If there are two (2) or more gates in any single development, all gates must be operated in the same fashion. 
(6)  A manual override shall be provided for use in the event of malfunction of any gate required to be opened electrically. 
(7)  Gate activation shall not be altered or placed out of service without prior notification to the Fire Rescue Department and police dispatch. Where prior approved activation gates become worn or inoperative, the approved radio transceiver shall replace them. 
(8)  The maintenance and upkeep of all gates, including the power and phone utility to operate the gates, shall be the responsibility of the property owner, homeowners' association, or occupants of a gated community. All gates must be serviced on at least an annual basis and a copy of the annual service performed shall be submitted to the Town Fire Rescue Department. 
(9)  All automatic gate opening devices shall include a timing device that will hold the gate open for the amount of time specified by the Town emergency service providers. 
(10)  Upon application for exemption, and approval by the Town Fire Department, an exemption from the requirements of this Ordinance shall be granted for the following uses, so long as an acceptable emergency response plan is agreed to by the Town and the property owner: 
a.  Security sensitive facilities including, but not limited to, law enforcement detention centers, prisons or jails, juvenile detention centers, public utilities and similar properties, or 
b.  Areas secured for the purpose of protecting equipment, vehicles machinery, goods, products, vacant or undeveloped property, or similar uses which are neither open to public access nor occupied or inhabited by any resident or employee. 
(11)  Any existing gate that does not conform to the requirements of this section shall either be retrofitted with the approved opening devices or removed no later than six (6) months following the adoption of this article. 
(d)  If gates are guarded on a twenty-four-hour, seven-day per week basis, the gate access control design standards and guidelines of subsection (c)(1) and (c)(9) are not applicable. All such guarded gates shall be promptly opened by the guard or attendant upon the approach of an emergency vehicle. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-26, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
Chapter 8 - GARBAGE AND REFUSE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, adopted June 7, 2011, repealed and replaced ch. 8, in its entirety. Former ch. 8 pertained to similar subject matter and was derived from Ord. No. O-2004-16, adopted May 4, 2004. 
Cross reference- Construction litter, §§ 4-1, 4-3; streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 16. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following words, terms and phrases shall have meanings as follows: 
    Appliances and white goods: Metal items including but not limited to refrigerators, freezers, washing machines, dryers, hot water heaters, cooking stoves, air conditioner units. 
    Ashes: Solid waste resulting from the burning of wood, coal, coke or other combustible material. 
    Bulky items: Large items that cannot fit into a rollout container and are acceptable for recycling or disposal in a landfill including furniture, mattresses and similar items. 
    Bulky yard waste: Vegetative matter resulting from landscaping maintenance that is greater than one (1) inch in diameter and does not exceed four (4) inches in diameter and is less than six (6) feet in length, or that will not fit in the yard waste cart due to its volume or size, and is banned from landfill disposal. 
    Collection: Removal of solid waste from premises within the corporate limits of the Town. 
    Compactor: Device designed to receive refuse and compact refuse into a stationary container. 
    Construction and demolition waste: Scrap building material from the construction, reconstruction, remodeling or repair of a building, walkway, driveway, sign or other structure, including but not limited to excavated earth, tree stumps, rocks, gravel, bricks, plaster, concrete, lumber or any other similar material used in construction or the containers or wrappings used for construction materials. 
    Contractor : An entity whose purpose is to provide work or services in exchange for a fee. 
    Department: The Town of Kernersville Public Services Department. 
    Director: The Director of Public Services or his/her authorized agent. 
    Disability: A medical condition that makes an individual unable to transport the rollout container to the curbside for collection. 
    Disability Household : A household where at least one person has a licensed physician letter or note documenting the disability as defined herein and there is no one else residing in the household capable of taking the rollout container to the curbside. 
    Dumpster: Any container designed to be serviced by a means of a forked frontloading vehicle, or by means of a hoist-mechanism. 
    Extra garbage: Bagged refuse that cannot fit inside the rollout container or be collected with the bulky items. 
    Household Hazardous Waste: Household products that contain corrosive, toxic, ignitable, or reactive ingredients, including but not limited to paints, cleaners, solvents, oils, batteries, and pesticides, that contain potentially hazardous ingredients and have been deemed potentially hazardous to human and environmental health by the Environmental Protection Agency, the State of North Carolina, and/or the County of Forsyth. 
    Multifamily dwelling: Any building designed for and containing two (2) or more dwelling units. 
    Nonresidential collection: Collection from any source other than a residence. 
    Prohibited Items: Waste that is prohibited from disposal in Town-owned solid waste containers in accordance with the solid waste policy, including dumpsters, rollout containers, recycling bins, recycling carts, yard waste carts, or any other collection container owned or serviced by the Town. 
    Refuse: Wastes bound for a municipal solid waste landfill. 
    Recyclable material: Those items that are approved for recycling within the Town limits as defined by the Director. The official list of materials acceptable for recycling can be found in the solid waste policy, a copy of which shall be available on the Town web site and at the office of ____________ . 
    Recycling Bin: The Town-approved recycling box-style container utilized for the collection of commingled recyclables within the Town of Kernersville. 
    Recycling Cart: The Town-approved wheeled container utilized for the collection of commingled recyclables within the Town of Kernersville. 
    Restaurant: A place of business where food is prepared and/or served, including cafeterias and establishments or facilities having in-house meal preparations.. 
    Rollout container: The Town approved wheeled container used for refuse collection within the Town of Kernersville. 
    Single-family dwelling: A structure used exclusively as a place of residence for one (1) family. 
    Solid waste: Discarded solid materials, including solid waste materials resulting from residential and nonresidential sources, including, but not limited to businesses, industrial, commercial and agricultural operations, and from community activities, and excluding solids or dissolved material in domestic sewage or other significant pollutants in water resources, such as silt, dissolved or suspended solids in industrial wastewater effluents, dissolved materials in irrigation return flows or other common water pollutants. 
    Solid Waste Policy: That written policy of the Town of Kernersville establishing, defining, delineating and promulgating general operations of the Public Services Department Solid Waste Division. 
    Town: Town of Kernersville, North Carolina. 
    Yard waste: Vegetative solid waste resulting from landscaping maintenance, including but not limited to: twigs, hedge trimmings, plant trimmings, grass clipping, leaves, shrubs and tree limbs less than one (1) inch in diameter, and excluding earth and soil, which will fit in the Town-approved yard waste cart and are banned from landfill disposal. 
    Yard waste cart: The Town approved wheeled container used for loose yard waste collection within the Town of Kernersville 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-2. - Administration and enforcement. 
(a)  The collection and removal of all solid waste within the corporate limits of the Town shall be under the jurisdiction of the Director. 
(b)  The Director and the Director's agents shall have the right to enter at any time on all premises for the purpose of making collections and inspections as required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-3. - Approved containers. 
    No person shall throw, place or deposit any solid waste of any kind upon any public or private property except in approved containers or as otherwise required by this chapter. The Town has authorized the rollout container, recycling cart, yard waste cart, dumpster and recycling bin as approved containers. 
    The Town shall provide one roll out container per single family dwelling. 
    Should the roll out container not provide sufficient storage between collections the resident may have one (1) additional roll out container for the fee established in the annual Schedule of Fees and Charges. 
    The Town reserves the right not to service any approved container that contains any material that should not be placed in the specific type of container or that does not otherwise meet the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-4. - Accumulations. 
    All solid waste shall be collected and placed in containers as required by this chapter, and it shall be unlawful for any person to permit solid waste to accumulate or remain on any premises longer than is reasonably necessary to remove and deposit same in approved containers. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-5. - Dead animals. 
    Small dead animals will be removed from any public street and any right-of-way of the Town upon notice to the department during normal business hours. No dead animals will be collected that are placed in rollout containers or from private property. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-6. - Interfering with solid waste of another. 
    No person shall handle, remove or add to the contents of any roll out container, yard waste cart, recycling bin or dumpster not owned by, leased by, or otherwise assigned to the use of such person without the prior permission of the owner of such container or other person legally entitled to the use of the same. This section shall not apply to the action of any solid waste employee acting within the scope of his employment. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011; Ord. No. O-2014-33, § 1, 12-2-2014) 
Sec. 8-7. - Interference with container of another. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to damage, displace, or to otherwise interfere with any roll out container, yard waste cart, recycling bin or dumpster except the owner or lessee thereof or upon permission of or at the request of the owner or lessee. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-8. - Liquids and ashes. 
(a)  All solid waste shall have the liquid drained there from. 
(b)  Ashes and cinders shall be placed in a separate container intended for that purpose. No ashes shall be deposited in any container until they are cold. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-9. - Reserved. 
Sec. 8-10. - Collection fees. 
    The charges for solid waste collection and disposal defined in this article shall be set forth in, and authorized by, the Schedule of Fees and Charges adopted with the Town budget ordinance for each fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-11. - Penalties and remedies. 
(a)  Any violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a misdemeanor as provided for in G.S. § 14-4 and shall be punishable by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days. 
(b)  Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall further be subject to the assessment of a civil penalty authorized by G.S. § 160A-175(c) in the amount of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for each violation. After being notified of a violation set forth in said notice and upon failure to remedy the violation within the time specified, a civil penalty shall be imposed in the form of a citation stating the nature of the violation, and the amount of the civil penalty. The citation shall direct the violator to pay the civil penalty within fifteen (15) days from the date of the citation. Such citation shall be served by either first class mail, personal service or by posting the front door of the primary structure on the premises. If payment is not received within fifteen (15) days, a civil action in the nature of a debt to collect the civil penalty may be instituted. 
(c)  Each day of violation of any provision of this chapter, after the offending individual or entity has been notified of such violation, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  Any violation of this chapter shall also be cause for discontinuance of solid waste collection and disposal service by the Town for the offending individual or entity. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Secs. 8-12-8-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION SERVICE 

Sec. 8-31. - Availability and extent of service. 
    The Town will collect, remove and dispose of only those solid wastes generated within the corporate limits except for collections from commercial entities.. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-32. - Nonresidential collections, 
(a)  Nonresidential solid waste collections may be provided by the Town, in accordance with the solid waste policy. 
(b)  Solid waste generated by restaurants shall be collected at least two times per week. 
(c)  Nonresidential collection of Old Corrugated Cardboard (OCC) may be provided in accordance with the solid waste policy. OCC must be completely separated from other solid waste. If contamination of the OCC is found before collection is attempted, the department reserves the right to refuse service and it will be the responsibility of the entity generating the waste to dispose of it. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-33. - Residential service. 
(a)  Single-family dwellings . Collection service to single-family dwellings will be in accordance with the solid waste policy. Collection will be on a weekly basis and shall be collected curbside except for disability households, at which collection shall be in accordance with department policy. 
(b)  Multifamily dwellings. Collection service to multifamily dwellings will be in accordance with subsection (a) herein except that all such dwellings having more than five (5) units will be serviced in accordance with section 8-34. Collection service to multi-family dwellings in which a roll-off type compactor has been provided by a developer, property owner, property owners association, or private firm shall be collected by a private solid waste management firm. 
(c)  Mobile homes, mobile home developments. Collection services to mobile homes and mobile home developments will be in accordance with subsection (a) herein except that all dwellings having more than five (5) units will be serviced in accordance with section 8-34. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-34. - Residential refuse dumpster service. 
    Multifamily dwellings containing six (6) or more individual living units, and mobile home developments having six (6) or more individually occupied lots, shall provide refuse dumpsters. All mobile home developments, and multifamily dwellings having sixteen (16) or more units, shall have no more nor no less than one (1) eight-yard refuse dumpster per sixteen (16) living units. For all mobile home developments and multifamily dwellings having between six (6) and fifteen (15) living units, the Director shall designate the appropriate size and number of refuse dumpsters such person shall be required to provide. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-35. - Curbside collection of garbage. 
(a)  A separate curbside collection of solid waste will be provided for each single-family dwelling. Refuse and recycling collection will not be provided to either vacant lots, or to lots having a portion of the property within the Town corporate limits but having the dwelling itself outside the corporate limits of the Town. 
(b)  Collection service will be provided in accordance with the solid waste policy. 
(c)  Solid Waste. Solid Waste will be collected at the curb in accordance with the schedule established by the Director. All solid waste must fit in the approved container that corresponds to the type of solid waste disposed. 
(d)  Extra garbage bags. Extra garbage bags will not be collected except during special clean-up periods established by the Director. Extra garbage will be collected in plastic garbage bags only. 
(e)  Appliances and white goods. Appliances and white goods will be collected at the curb on an as-needed or call-in basis. 
(f)  Bulky items. Bulky Items will be collected four times a year in accordance with the Solid Waste Policy and scheduled established by the Director . 
(g)  Extra corrugated cardboard: Corrugated cardboard generated by residents in volumes that exceed the capacity of the Town-approved recycling bin or recycling cart will be collected weekly on an as needed basis. Extra cardboard boxes must be flattened or broken down, and stacked neatly at the curb. Extra cardboard must be free of refuse, packing materials, and other contaminants as determined in the solid waste policy. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-36. - Prohibited collections. 
(a)  The Town will not collect any of the following prohibited items: automobile frames and parts; earth; lead-acid batteries; tires; wood with any cross section dimensions larger than four (4) inches or longer than six (6) feet; infectious or hazardous waste; household hazardous waste; animal or human excreta; rocks; burning or smoldering materials: asbestos; solid or liquid special waste prohibited by state or federal law. 
(b)  No construction and demolition waste shall be collected from houses nor other structures of work being performed by contractors for new structures, remodeling or repair of a building or any other structure. 
(c)  The Town shall not collect any material or refuse in its operations that is banned from the landfill by local, state, or federal law, or regulations imposed at the approved landfill utilized for waste disposal. Banned materials are prohibited from placement in all Town-owned containers. Recyclable materials that are banned from landfill disposal are banned from Town refuse containers but may be placed either in Town recycling containers or at the curb in accordance with the Solid Waste Policy. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-37. - Yard waste, loose leaves and pine needles, bulky yard waste, garbage and bulky items. 
(a)  Yard waste. Yard waste of all types is banned from landfill disposal and must be kept separate from all other solid waste. Except for seasonal leaf collection, yard waste will be collected at the curb in the approved yard waste cart only. 
(b)  Leaves . Leaves will be collected via vacuum service during time periods established by the Director. Loose leaves and pine needles containing sticks or other debris will not be collected if the Director determines that collection could be hazardous to the employees or equipment utilized by the Town for vacuum service. Leaves must be piled behind the curb line of the street, or where no curb line exists, leaves shall be kept off of the street. In the event that leaves are placed in a location that poses a traffic, pedestrian, stormwater, or safety hazard, they must be removed by the owner or party responsible for placing the leaves. Leaves may also be placed in yard waste carts for collection on a year-round basis. Leaves are banned from landfill disposal and must be separated from all other solid waste for collection; leaves are prohibited from disposal with any landfill-bound solid waste. 
(c)  Bulky yard waste. Bulky yard waste will be collected at the curb in accordance with the schedule established by the solid waste policy. Bulky yard waste collection will also be charged in accordance with the fees established in the Schedule of Fees and Charges. Bulky yard waste items such as tree limbs and branches shall not exceed four (4) inches in diameter and shall be cut in lengths no longer than six (6) feet. Bulky yard waste must be stacked neatly with the cut ends facing the street. Bulky yard waste is banned from landfill disposal and must be separated from all other solid waste for collection. 
Bulky yard waste products will be collected by the Town when the tree trimming and yard work has been performed by the property owner or occupant of the single-family house. When work that generates bulky yard waste is contracted to landscapers, tree service contractors or other commercial workers, the contracting party is responsible for the removal and disposal of all products. The Town assumes no obligation to remove and dispose of bulky yard waste, vegetative and wood products or other similar material resulting from the clearing or landscaping of large acreage tracts or development of vacant lots. Any person who is hired to perform such work shall remove and dispose of such products and similar materials within seven (7) days. 
(d)  Garbage. Garbage will be collected at the curb in accordance with the schedule established by the solid waste policy. All garbage must fit in the approved rollout container to be collected. Bags of extra garbage will not be collected except during special clean up periods established by the department. 
(e)  Bulky items, appliances and white goods. Appliances, bulky items and white goods will be collected at the curb, four times a year in accordance with the established schedule. Overflow volumes of bagged garbage will not be collected as bulky items. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011; Ord. No. O-2014-33, § 2, 12-2-2014) 
Sec. 8-38. - Special bulk collections. 
(a)  Any property owner and/or resident who cannot place bulky items at the curb as provided for in section 8-37 shall either personally dispose of the bulky items, or call the department and schedule a dumpster to be delivered. These collections are provided at a fee established by the Board of Alderman on an annual basis in the Schedule of Fees and Charges. 
(b)  Attic, basement and special cleanings collections will be offered by the Town during special clean up periods as established by the department. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011; Ord. No. O-2014-33, § 3, 12-2-2014) 
Secs. 8-39-8-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONTAINERS 

Sec. 8-56. - Required. 
    Every building or premises where garbage or refuse may be generated or exist must have appropriate containers as specified in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-57. - Single-family residential. 
    Residential refuse containers shall be the approved rollout container provided by the Town. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-58. - Multifamily residential. 
    Refuse dumpsters shall be required at all apartments, condominiums, and other multiple dwelling structures having six (6) or more living units. 
    Multifamily complexes without sufficient space or clearance to be serviced by dumpsters must utilize the approved rollout container. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-59. - Mobile home parks. 
    All mobile home developments, trailer courts, and similar places, which contain six (6) or more lots, shall provide refuse dumpsters. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-60. - Nonresidential collections. 
(a)  All nonresidential establishments including, but not limited to commercial, industrial, manufacturing, office buildings and restaurants, shall utilize refuse dumpsters unless: 
(1)  Low volume disposers combine their refuse with adjoining or nearby businesses and share in the use of a refuse dumpster; or 
(2)  The demographic location of the business is not consistent with current front-loader routes of the Town thus making it more economical and efficient for the Town to recommend the use of residential refuse containers; or 
(3)  The Director has determined the volume of waste does not justify a refuse dumpster. The prevailing collection rate will apply to all nonresidential customers that use a rollout rather than a dumpster. 
(b)  All exceptions listed above and together with any other exceptions, shall be approved by the Director. In those situations where a refuse dumpster is not necessary, the container requirements of section 8-57 shall apply. 
(c)  Refuse dumpsters shall have a minimum capacity of four (4) cubic yards and a maximum of eight (8) cubic yards. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-61. - Recycling. 
    The Town provides the opportunity for residents to place certain recyclable waste at the curb for pick up. Each resident is furnished with one (1) recycling bin and additional bins are available upon request. Recycling bins should be placed at the curb by 7:00 a.m. on the scheduled collection day and be removed by 7:00 p.m. that same day. Only recyclable items are allowed in the recycling bin. 
    Recycling collections are provided at a fee established by the Board of Alderman on an annual basis in the Schedule of Fees and Charges. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011; Ord. No. O-2014-33, § 3, 12-2-2014) 
Sec. 8-62. - Placement. 
(a)  Residential refuse containers. All residential refuse containers shall be placed at the curb or edge of pavement prior to 7:00 a.m. on the collection day and removed by 7:00 p.m. on your collection day. Rollout containers shall be easily accessible and in no way obstructed. City collection personnel shall not provide service if denied reasonable access by parked vehicles, equipment, fixed objects, low hanging wires or other obstructions. 
(b)  Refuse dumpsters. Each establishment shall provide a concrete or asphalt pad upon which each refuse dumpster shall be placed. Required specifications for such pads as defined by the Town design construction manual are summarized below: 
(1)  For pickup on a driveway or parking lot there shall be required a four-thousand-pound mixture of concrete or asphalt for a pad ten (10) feet wide, fourteen (14) feet long and eight (8) inches thick. 
(2)  The location of the pad for refuse dumpsters shall be on a straight driveway at least forty-two (42) feet in length. The approval of the Director shall be obtained for proper placement of the refuse dumpster pad. 
(3)  Refuse dumpsters shall be located so as to provide easy ingress and egress by a front loading collection truck designed to service refuse dumpster(s). The location of the refuse dumpster shall be free from any overhanging wires or other obstructions which are less than thirty-five (35) feet vertical clearance, forty (40) vertical clearance of over head obstruction in the dumping area. All screens or enclosures shall be open on one side for ease access and provide a three-foot clearance on all sides from the refuse dumpster. The refuse dumpster may be enclosed on all sides, provided that it is opened by the owner of all scheduled collection days. 
(4)  The Town design construction manual is available for those wishing to see a detail construction diagram. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-63. - Blocking access. 
(a)  No person shall in any manner obstruct, nor allow to be obstructed, access to any refuse container. 
(b)  All refuse dumpster containers shall be marked with. "No Parking" or "No Blocking" signs clearly visible; 
(c)  When a vehicle or other obstruction blocks access to any refuse dumpster, the Town will not service the dumpster until the next scheduled collection day. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-64. - Maintenance. 
(a)  The owner or lessee of a refuse dumpster serviced by the Town shall be responsible for any repairs to such refuse dumpster, driveways, and access drives. Upon notice by the Town that the refuse dumpster is unsafe or needs repair, such owner or lessee shall, within seven (7) days of such notice, replace or repair the same to a safe sanitary condition. If the dumpster is not repaired within seven (7) days, the Town will not service the dumpster until the repair is completed. 
(b)  The owner or lessee of any refuse dumpster serviced by the Town shall: 
(1)  Keep such dumpster in a clean, sanitary, rust-free condition; 
(2)  Keep the ground area surrounding the dumpster clean and free of litter; 
(3)  Place only garbage or refuse (compactable material) into such dumpster; and 
(4)  Place no material(s), including but not limited to wood, wooden pallets, metal, tires, appliances, white goods, liquids, hazardous materials, yard waste gas tanks or any item or material banned from disposal in North Carolina landfills in such dumpster. 
(c)  The owner or lessee of a refuse dumpster serviced by the Town shall not allow, nor permit, garbage or refuse to accumulate on top of, or around, the refuse dumpster or refuse dumpster site. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-65. - Unusable containers. 
    No person or entity shall use any refuse container(s) used in the residential or nonresidential collection of solid waste which are rusted or broken or are, in any manner, unable to adequately contain solid waste in a satisfactory manner or which pose a threat of injury to any individual including employees of the Town engaged in the collection process. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-7-2011)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 8.5-1-8.5-20. - Reserved.

Sec. 8.5-21. - Incorporation by reference.
