(3)  The application contains a material falsehood or misrepresentation; 
(4)  The applicant is legally incompetent to contract or to sue and be sued; 
(5)  The applicant has on prior occasions made material misrepresentations regarding the nature or scope of an event; 
(6)  The applicant has previously permitted a violation or has violated the terms of a public assembly or parade permit issued to or on behalf of the applicant; 
(7)  The applicant has on prior occasions damaged Town property and has not paid in full for such damage; 
(8)  A fully executed prior application for the same time and place has been received, and a permit has been or will be granted to a prior applicant authorizing uses or activities which do not reasonably permit multiple simultaneous events; 
(9)  The proposed event would conflict with previously planned programs organized, conducted, or sponsored by the Town and previously scheduled at or near the same time and place; 
(10)  The proposed event would present an unreasonable danger to the public health or safety; 
(11)  The proposed event would substantially or unnecessarily interfere with traffic; 
(12)  The event would likely interfere with the movement of emergency equipment and police protection in areas contiguous or in the vicinity of the event; 
(13)  There would not, at the time of the event, be sufficient law enforcement and traffic control officers to adequately protect participants and non-participants from traffic related hazards in light of the other demands for police protection at the time of the proposed event; 
(14)  The applicant has not complied or cannot comply with applicable licensure requirements, ordinances or regulations concerning the sale or offering for sale of any goods or services; 
(15)  The use or activity intended by the applicant is prohibited by law; 
(16)  For non-First Amendment protected public assemblies or parades, the following criteria shall also apply: 
a.  The cultural and/or educational significance of the event; 
b.  The extent to which the event contributes to the economic revitalization and business development of the Town; 
c.  The impact and/or cost of the event to Town support services; 
d.  The impact of the event to the public health, safety and welfare; 
e.  The impact of the event on business and resident populations within or adjacent to the proposed event site; 
f.  The evaluation of any previous event produced by the event organizer with regard to planning, number of attendees, quality, public safety, and payment of invoices; 
g.  The frequency and timing of the event or similar events. 
    Unless subject to (c)(16), nothing in this section shall authorize the permit official to deny or revoke a permit based upon political, social, or religious grounds or reasons, or based upon the content of the views expressed. 
    The permit official may attach reasonable conditions to any permit approval. 
(d)  Costs and fees. The applicant shall be responsible for hiring and paying off-duty law enforcement officers, or reimbursing the Town for the costs of providing on-duty law enforcement officers to appropriately police street closures. For festivals, the applicant shall be additionally responsible for hiring and paying off-duty law enforcement officers and fire/EMS personnel, or reimbursing the Town for the costs of providing on-duty law enforcement officers and fire/EMS personnel, to provide internal festival safety and security. 
    The permit official, in consultation with the Town Police and Fire Rescue Departments, shall determine the number of officers and fire/EMS personnel needed to appropriately police street closures and for internal safety and security, and the time when such services shall commence and end, taking into consideration the following: 
(1)  The proposed location of the special event or route of the parade; 
(2)  The time of day that the public assembly or parade is to take place; 
(3)  The date and day of the week proposed; 
(4)  The general traffic conditions in the area requested, both vehicular and pedestrian. Special attention is given to the rerouting of the vehicles or pedestrians normally using the requested area; 
(5)  The number of marked and unmarked intersections along the route requested, together with the traffic control devices present; 
(6)  If traffic must be completely rerouted from the area, then the number of marked and unmarked intersections and the traffic control devices are to be taken into consideration; 
(7)  The estimated number of participants; 
(8)  The estimated number of viewers; 
(9)  The nature, composition, format and configuration of the special event or parade; 
(10)  The anticipated weather conditions; 
(11)  The estimated time for the special event or parade; 
(12)  For festivals, whether live music will be offered, or retail sales stations provided, and the number and location of music stages, and retail stands. 
    In addition, for festivals, the applicant shall reimburse the Town for the costs of providing street and sidewalk cleaning, trash receptacle placement, trash removal, and trash disposal. 
    Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Town may provide the services required by this subsection at no cost, or at a reduced cost, to the applicant should the Town desire to provide such support to the public assembly or parade. Such action is not a waiver of a regulatory requirement based upon political, social, or religious grounds or reasons, or based upon the content of the views expressed, but instead is an affirmative act of Town association or speech. 
(e)  Time and notice of decision. The permit official shall approve or deny an application within twenty (20) days of receipt. A notice of denial or revocation shall clearly set forth the grounds upon which the permit was denied or revoked and, where feasible, shall contain a proposal for measures by which the applicant may cure any defects in the application or otherwise procure a permit. Where an application is denied because the proposed event would conflict with another event that has or will be approved, the permit official shall propose an alternative place, if available for the same time, or an alternative time, if available for the same place. 
(f)  Appeals. 
(1)  An applicant may appeal the denial or revocation of an application in writing within ten (10) days after notice of the denial has been received. Within five (5) business days, or such longer period of time agreed to by the applicant, the appeals official shall hold a quasi-judicial hearing on whether to issue the permit or uphold the denial or revocation. The applicant shall have the right to present evidence at said hearing. The decision to issue or uphold the denial or revocation shall be based solely on the approval criteria set forth in this section. The appeals official shall render a decision on the appeal within five (5) business days after the date of the hearing. In the event that the purpose of the proposed event is a spontaneous response to a current event, or where other good and compelling causes are shown, the appeals official shall reasonably attempt to conduct the hearing and render a decision on the appeal as expeditiously as is practicable. 
(2)  The decision of the appeals official is subject to judicial review. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision of this section or to violate any term or condition of a permit issued pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 2013-24, § 1, 11-12-2013; Ord. No. O-2014-33, § 5, 12-2-2014) 
Sec. 12-22. - Public assembly and parade regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to unreasonably hamper, obstruct, impede, or interfere with a public assembly or parade, or with any person, vehicle, or animal participating or used in the public assembly or parade. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of a motor vehicle to drive between vehicles or persons comprising a parade when such vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. 
(c)  Spectators of a public assembly or parade and persons attending or participating in a public assembly or parade picketing shall be subject to all applicable local, state and federal laws including, but not limited to G.S. § 14-277.2 (weapons). 
(d)  Nothing in this section prohibits a law enforcement officer from issuing a command to disperse in accordance with G.S. § 14-288.5 in the event of a riot or disorderly conduct by an assemblage of three (3) or more persons. 
(Ord. No. 2013-24, § 1, 11-12-2013) 
Chapter 13 - POLICE DEPARTMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-25, § 1, adopted November 12, 2013, repealed and replaced ch. 13, §§ 13-1-13-5, in its entirety. Former ch. 13 pertained to similar subject matter and was derived from Code 1980, §§ 3-1001-3-1006, 7-1024, 7-1025 and Ord. of 11-9-82. 
Charter reference- Police chief, extraterritorial police jurisdiction, § 18. 
Cross reference- Emergency vehicles, §§ 9-5, 9-6. 

Sec. 13-1. - Composition. 
    The Police Department of the Town shall consist of a Chief of Police and Officers, and other personnel, as the Chief of Police deems necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2013-25, § 1, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 13-2. - Chief. 
(a)  The Chief of Police shall be primarily responsible for the enforcement of law and preservation of peace and good order within the Police jurisdiction of the Town, and shall have and exercise all lawful authority necessary for such purposes. 
(b)  The Chief of Police, under the general supervision of the Town Manager, shall have charge of the Police Department and shall exercise command over the Police force, and other personnel. The Chief shall be responsible to the Town Manager in seeing that the Police Officers and other personnel faithfully perform their duties. 
(c)  The Chief shall perform such other functions as may be required by Ordinance or by the Town Manager. 
(Ord. No. 2013-25, § 1, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 13-3. - Duties of Police Officers. 
    It shall be the duty of Police Officers to: 
(1)  Perform general duty law enforcement work to protect life and property in the Town; 
(2)  Patrol the Town; 
(3)  Prevent, detect, and investigate disturbances and crimes; 
(4)  Perform traffic-control; 
(5)  Apprehend suspects; 
(6)  Maintain surveillance and observation for stolen vehicles, other stolen property missing persons, and persons suspected of violating the laws; 
(7)  Regulate and direct vehicular and pedestrian traffic at school crossings, street intersections, and accident scenes; escort funerals, and maintain order at public gatherings; 
(8)  Perform investigations of accidents, complaints, and crimes; interview witnesses, gather and preserve evidence, and present testimony in court; 
(9)  Issue citations for violation of traffic and parking regulations; 
(10)  Procurement and service of criminal summons, warrants and other legal papers; and 
(11)  Exercise all the powers invested in law-enforcement officers by statute or common law within one mile of the corporate limits of the city, and on all property owned by or leased to the Town wherever located and pursuant to any mutual aid agreements entered into by the Town; and 
(12)  Provide assistance, protection and security for schools within the Kernersville corporate limits. 
(Ord. No. 2013-25, § 1, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 13-4. - Authority as to Motor Vehicles and Traffic. 
(a)  The Officers of the Police Department or such Officers as are assigned by the Chief of Police shall enforce all municipal vehicular and traffic ordinances and all of the state statutes applicable to vehicular traffic. 
(b)  Officers of the Police Department or such Officers as are assigned by the Chief of Police are hereby authorized to direct all vehicular and pedestrian traffic by voice, hand, or signal in conformance with Town ordinances and State statutes; provided that, in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, Officers of the Police Department may direct traffic as conditions may require notwithstanding the provisions of the aforementioned ordinances and statutes. 
(c)  Officers of the Fire Rescue Department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct or assist the Police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity. 
(d)  No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a Police Officer or Fire Rescue Department Official while in the course of their duty. 
(Ord. No. 2013-25, § 1, 11-12-2013) 
Chapter 14 - RAILROADS AND TRAINS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2013-13, § 1, adopted June 25, 2013, amended ch. 14, §§ 14-1-14-6, to read as set out herein. Prior to its adoption ch. 14 pertained to similar subject matter and was derived from Code 1980, §§ 7-1231-7-1237. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 16. 

Sec. 14-1. - Time limit for blockages. 
    It shall be unlawful for any railroad company or agent or employee of such company to permit a train or any part thereof to remain standing across any street in the Town for a longer period than five (5) minutes. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-13, § 1, 6-25-2013) 
Sec. 14-2. - Clearing crossings in emergencies. 
    Every person in charge of a railroad train which is standing at a street crossing shall clear the crossing upon the sounding of a fire alarm, the approach of a vehicle of the Police or Fire Rescue Department, or when requested so to do by the Chief of the Fire Rescue Department, a Police Officer or the driver of an ambulance. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-13, § 1, 6-25-2013) 
Sec. 14-3. - Backing over crossing. 
    No railroad train shall be backed across any street crossing in the Town unless some member of the train crew is stationed at the crossing to notify or stop traffic in the advance of the movement. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-13, § 1, 6-25-2013) 
Sec. 14-4. - Jumping on or off, clinging to, etc., moving trains. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to jump on or off, or to cling to or hang on any railroad car or engine in the Town while the same is in motion. This section shall not apply to any employee of the railroad. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-13, § 1, 6-25-2013) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles, §§ 9-8-9-10. 
Sec. 14-5. - Sounding of warning device. 
(a)  No person shall run on or across any street or highway within the corporate limits of the Town any railroad engine or locomotive without sounding the customary warning device attached thereto during the time the engine or locomotive is in motion. 
(b)  No person shall sound any customary warning device, except at street crossings to give warnings to persons or animals in peril, or in other cases of necessity. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-13, § 1, 6-25-2013) 
Cross reference- Noise, § 10-81 et seq. 
Chapter 15 - SEWAGE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---

Former ch. 15 pertained to similar subject matter and was derived from Code 1980, §§ 5-2001(1)-(6), (7)(a)-(g), (h)(1)-(10), (i)(1-4), (j)(1)-(8), (10), (k), (l), (m), (8)(a), (b), (d), (9), (10), 5-2002(1), (2)(a)-(c)(1)-(4), (d), (3)(a)-(f), (g)(1), (2), (h)-(j), (4)(a)-(c), (5)(a), (b), (6)(a)-(e), (7), (8), (10), 5-2003(1), (2), (3)(a)-(d), (4)-(7), 5-2004(1)(a)-(e), (2)(a)-(c), (3), 5-2005(1)(a)-(e), (3), (5), (6); Ord. Sec. 15-1. - Sewerage system policy. 
(a)  The Water and Sewerage System Policy Resolutions, prepared for the City of Winston-Salem, and adopted by the City/County Utility Commission on July 8, 1996, together with subsequent amendments, are hereby adopted as the sewerage system policy of the Town for enforcement purposes, and are incorporated into this chapter by reference. A copy of such resolution is on file and available in the Town Clerk's office. 
(b)  A violation of any provision, or part thereof, of the sewer use resolution shall constitute a misdemeanor and shall subject the offender to a fine of not more than $500.00 or imprisonment for not more than 30 days. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-05, § 4, 1-5-2010)

Chapter 16 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2014-02, adopted January 7, 2014, amended ch. 16, to read as set out herein. Prior to its adoption ch. 16 pertained to similar subject matter and was derived from Code 1980, §§ 4-1002, 4-1003, 4-1006(a)-(c), 4-1007, 4-1009, 4-1012-4-1014, 4-1021, 4-1023, 4-1025(1)-(4), 4-1051-4-1055, 4-1071-4-1074, 6-2001-6-2010, 6-2012-6-2014, 7-1040, 7-1097, 7-1110; Ord. of 4-6-81; Ord. No. 96-07, adopted March 5, 1996; Ord. No. 99-23, adopted September 7, 1999 and Ord. No. 01-44, adopted November 8, 2001. 
Charter reference- Title to land under streets, sidewalks, alleys, § 24; street improvements and assessments therefor, § 25; repair of sidewalks, § 26. 
Cross reference- Civil emergencies, Ch. 6; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 9; parades, pickets and group demonstrations, Ch. 12; railroads and trains, Ch. 14; vehicles for hire, Ch. 17; unified development, Ch. 19. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Applicability. 
    All public squares and parks shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter and other ordinances relating to streets and sidewalks. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-2. - Falling guards, fences. 
    Every person owning any lot or land in the Town which is so much lower than the grade of the street, sidewalk or highway on which it borders as to create a dangerous condition, or on which there is a dangerous condition by reason of a hole, excavation or other cause, shall provide proper guards or a fence sufficiently high and strong to prevent persons from falling from the street or sidewalk into such lot or land. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-3. - House and yard trash. 
    No person shall put or cause to be put or placed, on any sidewalk or street, any house sweepings, yard sweepings, leaves, garbage, shavings, trash or other rubbish, except in such places and in such manner as the Board of Aldermen shall prescribe or provide. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Cross reference- Littering, § 11-9. 
Sec. 16-4. - Hindering drainage. 
    No person shall impede, dam or otherwise hinder the natural flow of drainage water from the streets, gutters, culverts, ditches or other natural or artificial channels designed or adopted for such use on, in or from any of the streets of the Town. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-5. - Drainage from downspouts, air conditioners. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any building erected after January 1, 1979, or with the front thereafter altered or remodeled, located adjacent to a paved sidewalk, to empty water from any downspout on such building directly onto such sidewalk. The downspout water referred to shall be carried by a drain under the sidewalk and emptied onto the gutter. The owner shall obtain a permit from the Town for the construction of such drain at the owner's expense. This subsection shall not apply to existing downspouts in use as of January 1, 1979. 
(b)  It shall also be unlawful for the owner of any building maintaining air conditioning units on such building which overhang a sidewalk on which the building abuts, or for a tenant in such building owning an air conditioning unit, to permit water from such air conditioning unit to be discharged directly upon the sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-6. - Poisons, hazardous substances. 
    No person shall place or cause to be placed any strychnine, arsenic or other poisonous or hazardous substance, mixture or article, not exclusively covered by state law, in or upon any sidewalk, street, public way, public place, or in any lot or building within the Town, except upon their own premises. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-7. - Barbed wire. 
    No person shall construct or maintain on any premises along any streets or alleys of the Town any barbed wire or barbed-wire fence. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-8. - Construction in right-of-way. 
    No person shall install any drainpipe, ventilation pipe or do any type of construction in the street right-of-way without first submitting the plans for such work to the Director of Public Services for approval. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-9. - Obstructions. 
(a)  No person shall obstruct or suffer to be obstructed any street or sidewalk of the Town, except by permission of the Town Manager. 
(b)  No person shall park or drive any motor vehicle upon any sidewalk of the Town, except by permission of the Town Manager. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-10. - Charge for use of street. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, with the exception of the Town, to charge any other person for the use of any portion of any public street within the corporate limits. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-11. - Sale and display of goods. 
    No person shall obstruct Pedestrian traffic on any sidewalk or street of the Town by displaying, offering for sale or selling, at auction or otherwise, any goods, wares or merchandise thereon. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-12. - Reserved. 
Sec. 16-13. - Removal of barricade. 
    Any person other than an employee of the Town who shall take down or remove a barricade placed on any street or alley that is being paved or improved by the Town shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-14. - Moving of buildings and certain vehicles. 
(a)  No person shall move or assist in moving any building through any street, highway (except I-40), public way, or over any bridge or paved sidewalk within the Town, or operate or move a vehicle through the streets, ways, bridges or sidewalks without having first obtained a written permit on a form provided by the Town Manager. The fee for each such permit shall be paid in advance and may be found in the Schedule of Fees and Charges of the Town of Kernersville maintained in the Town Clerk's office as provided in section 1-9. 
(b)  No permit required by this section shall be issued unless a permit from the state Department of Transportation is displayed to the Town Manager, in the event the vehicle in question is to travel over state streets or highways. 
(c)  No permit for the moving of any building shall be issued until a bond, or certificate of insurance by an insurance company authorized to do business in North Carolina, and certified and endorsed by a local agent has been filed, conditioned that such permittee will pay any and all damages which may happen to any tree, pavement, street, or sidewalk, or to any awning, wire, fire or police alarm, telegraph or other pole, or to any other things injured by any such house mover, its agents, employees, or workmen; and conditioned also that such party will indemnify and save harmless the Town against all liabilities, judgments, costs and expense, which may in any way accrue against the Town in consequence of the granting of such permit; and that such party will in all things strictly comply with the conditions of the permit. The amount of bond or certificate of insurance shall be set in each case by the Board of Aldermen after having reviewed the proposed permit; in lieu of having the amount of bond or certificate of insurance set by the Board of Aldermen, the person, firm or corporation seeking the permit may post a bond or certificate of insurance in a standard amount, sufficient to cover the Town's liability, which shall be set from time to time by the Board of Aldermen and maintained on file by the Town Clerk. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014; Ord. No. O-2014-33, § 6, 12-2-2014) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 16-15. - Duty to keep sidewalks and gutters clear. 
(a)  Every owner or occupant of a lot on any street shall keep the sidewalk adjoining such lot clear and the gutter open and free from obstruction. If any rubbish, dirt, ashes or any other thing is placed or left without lawful authority upon such sidewalk or in such gutter, the owner or occupant of such lot shall remove the same. 
(b)  No person occupying premises within the business section of the Town shall permit any snow to remain on the sidewalk in front of such premises longer than four (4) hours, between sunrise and sunset, after the snow has ceased to fall. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-16. - Acts and conditions requiring special street cleaning or repair. 
(a)  Any act, neglect or omission, or any condition caused or allowed to continue, which creates or results in causing a condition in or upon any public street, sidewalk or storm drain which requires special cleaning or repair of such street, sidewalk or storm drain is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  Prohibited acts, neglects, omissions and conditions which result in requiring special cleaning or repair shall include but shall not be limited to: 
(1)  The hauling of dirt, debris or materials removed from the sites of construction or reconstruction of buildings or structures, or waste materials of any kind, in such manner that any portion of such dirt, debris or materials is spilled, lost, dropped or left upon the streets or sidewalks. 
(2)  The depositing or leaving upon the streets or sidewalks of mud, dirt or any other material as a result of the use of trucks, construction equipment or machinery, regardless of whether such materials are spilled, lost or dropped in transit or are deposited upon the surface of the street or public property by the tires or wheels of such trucks, construction equipment or machinery. 
(3)  The grading of lots, land or driveways at elevations higher than street or sidewalk level or any other acts, neglects or conditions created or allowed to exist upon such property which results in mud, dirt, soil, gravel, debris or other materials being washed onto streets or sidewalks or into the Town storm drainage system. 
(c)  "Special cleaning or repair" of streets, sidewalks and the storm drainage system shall be deemed to be "required" when their condition is such that the public health, safety, welfare or public use of the same is threatened, limited or impaired; the use and enjoyment of property abutting such streets or sidewalks is diminished or limited; or substantial damage is caused to the streets, sidewalks or drainage facilities or to such abutting property. The words "special cleaning or repair" shall include resurfacing, restoration of gravel and similar repairs made necessary by prohibited acts, neglects or conditions. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-16.1. - Town to clean streets requiring special repair; authority to require remedial actions. 
(a)  The Public Services Department may clean and repair any street, sidewalk, or storm drain when special cleaning or repair is required as defined in section 16-16. The Public Services Department will keep records of the costs of all such repairs or cleaning for reimbursement in accordance with section 16-16.2. 
(b)  The Building Inspector is hereby authorized to require the person(s) violating section 16-16 to take remedial actions in order to prevent ongoing violations of this article. Such actions shall include, but not be limited to, requirements to undertake stabilization control measures where land disturbing activity is occurring which creates runoff onto the streets, sidewalks or into the storm drainage system operated by the Town. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-16.2. - Penalty for violation of section 16-16 or 16-16.1. 
(a)  Any person who violates section 16-16 or 16-16.1 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Any person whose act, neglect, omission, or who, by permitting a condition to continue, whether done or neglected directly or through any agent, servant or employee, causes additional expenses to the Town for necessary special street, sidewalk, or storm drain cleaning or repair shall reimburse the Town of Kernersville for its expense upon receipt of an itemized statement of expense submitted by the Town. 
In addition to all other remedies provided for herein, any violation of this article subjects the offender to a civil penalty in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day that any person, firm, corporation or other entity remains in violation of this article. The civil penalty shall be in the nature of a debt and may be recovered by the Town in a civil action if the offender does not pay the penalty within sixty (60) days after being cited by written notice from the Town for violation of this article. 
The Town shall send to any person violating this article a statement showing the costs and civil penalty incurred. The Town Attorney is authorized to bring suit to recover any such unpaid penalties. 
(c)  A continuing violation of section 16-16 or 16-16.1 shall be a separate and distinct offense on each day on which it occurs. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-17. - Farm vehicles, treaded vehicles and heavy equipment. 
    No person shall drive over any hard-surfaced asphalt paved street, any agricultural machinery, including but not limited to harrows or like equipment, with sharp blades, discs or spikes that will drag on the pavement; or any traction engine with caterpillar wheels or any heavy piece of machinery that will in any way damage or injure the pavement. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-18. - Obstructing view at intersection. 
    No person, by signs, trees, shrubbery or structures, within twenty-five (25) feet of the intersection of curblines shall obstruct the view of approaching traffic at any intersection. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-19. - Proper condition of sidewalks. 
(a)  Every person or entity who/which constructs any new residential/commercial structure within the Town of Kernersville, pursuant to requirement(s) of the Board of Aldermen, ordinance(s), the Town of Kernersville Public Services Department Development Guidelines for Design and Construction and is required to install a sidewalk adjacent thereto, shall do so in a proper workmanlike manner according to such requirement(s) of the Board of Aldermen, ordinance(s), and/or the Town of Kernersville Public Services Department Development Guidelines for Design and Construction; 
(b)  The head of the Town of Kernersville Inspection Division or his/her designee shall inspect each sidewalk adjacent to such new residential/commercial structure where a sidewalk is a requirement of the Board of Aldermen, the ordinance(s), and/or the Town of Kernersville Public Services Department Development Guidelines for Design and Construction and the Building Inspections Division of the Fire Department shall not issue a "Certificate of Occupancy" ("CO") or "Building Final" approval for the structure until such required sidewalk is in a proper workmanlike condition free of any visual damage or until a cash bond has been placed with the Town in accordance with the estimate of repair/construction by the Town of Kernersville Public Services Department; 
(c)  The owner and/or future occupant of the residential/commercial structure subject to this section shall place the required sidewalk in a proper workmanlike condition, free of any visual damage, prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy; 
(d)  Every person(s) or entity(ies) who/which own property upon which there is situate a driveway connection, any portion of which encompasses a portion of or all of the sidewalk adjacent to said property, shall keep that portion of the said driveway connection in a proper and safe condition for pedestrian travel and shall repair/replace any such sidewalk which becomes damaged. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Secs. 16-20-16-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ENCROACHMENTS AND OVERHANGS 

Sec. 16-36. - Signs. 
    No person shall hang or suspend any sign over or above the sidewalks or streets of the Town at less than eight (8) feet from the ground over the sidewalk and less than fifteen (15) feet from the ground above the street. All such signs shall be installed under the supervision of the Building Inspector and shall be kept securely fastened at all times. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-37. - Hazards. 
    The Board of Aldermen shall cause all obstructions above, across or under the streets of the Town which, upon investigation, may be found dangerous or unsafe to the public using such street, to be removed. If, upon investigation, such obstruction shall be found dangerous or unsafe for the public using the street, the Board of Aldermen shall make and enter upon its minutes an order directing the person maintaining such obstructions, to remove the same within a reasonable time, not exceeding sixty (60) days. Any person failing or refusing to obey the order directing the removal of such obstruction shall be guilty of a violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-38. - Construction obstructing right-of-way. 
    No person shall build, erect, construct or place any porch, steps, fence, wall or other obstruction whatsoever in or on any of the streets, sidewalks or public alleys of the Town. Each day any such obstruction is allowed to remain, beginning on the tenth day after notice given by the Chief of Police or the Director of Public Services to remove the same, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-39. - Sheds, awnings. 
(a)  No person shall erect any awning or shed, supported by a post, across any sidewalk or street. 
(b)  Awnings projecting over any sidewalk shall be suspended from the buildings to which they are attached and shall be at least seven (7) feet above the sidewalk at the lowest point. 
(c)  No awning contractor or worker shall erect any awning or shed which does not conform to the requirements of this section. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of the building to which any awning is attached to erect or permit to remain any awning or shed which does not comply with the requirements of this section. 
(e)  Each day such unlawful obstruction is allowed to remain, after notice by the authorized Town official to remove the same, shall be a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-40. - Skids and planks for receiving goods. 
    Merchants or other persons who obstruct the sidewalks by placing skids or planks across the sidewalk for the purpose of receiving goods are required to remove such skids or planks as soon as the goods are loaded or unloaded, and any such person failing to promptly remove such skids or planks shall be guilty of violating this section. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Secs. 16-41-16-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CUTS AND EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 16-56. - Driveway permit. 
    No person shall cut any curb or to remove any curb, curbing or curbstone without a permit from the Town Manager or his designee. The Town Manager or his designee is authorized to sign state permits for driveways on state-maintained roads on behalf of the Town. The Board of Aldermen shall set fees for driveway permits in the Schedule of Fees and Charges of the Town of Kernersville. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014; Ord. No. O-2014-33, § 6, 12-2-2014) 
Sec. 16-57. - Excavation Permit. 
(a)  Required, fee. No trench, ditch or other excavation shall be made in the public streets, sidewalks or alleys or other public grounds of the Town nor shall any sidewalk, curbline or street be cut, placed or replaced unless a permit therefor shall have been obtained from the Town Manager or his designee. The fees for such permits shall be as prescribed by the Board of Aldermen in the Schedule of Fees and Charges of the Town of Kernersville. 
(b)  Application, contents. Such application shall set forth the name of the person, the name and/or location of the street, curb or sidewalk, the date construction is to begin, the approximate period of time allotted for construction, and the number of employees to be working on the project. 
(c)  Issuance. Upon approval of such application, the Public Services Director shall issue a permit to the applicant and may, in addition to the terms agreed to upon the application, impose additional conditions and stipulations on the construction. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014; Ord. No. O-2014-33, § 6, 12-2-2014) 
Sec. 16-58. - Replacement and repair. 
(a)  Materials, methods. Any person receiving a valid Excavation Permit shall be required to backfill/tamp any areas of construction to achieve a density of at least ninety-five percent (95%). All pavement shall be removed by cutting on a straight line with edges as vertical as possible. Materials to replace pavement shall be of the same composition of that removed. Prior to replacing asphalt pavement, an eight-inch compacted stone base shall be laid and tamped. 
(b)  Time. Pavement and sidewalk replacement shall be carried on as soon as possible after backfilling and tamping operations and in no case shall asphalt pavement cuts not be replaced within seven (7) days after compaction has been achieved. All pavement or sidewalk cuts shall be replaced and repaired within ten (10) days after construction is complete. 
(c)  Work by Town. It shall be the sole responsibility of the permittee to maintain pavement and sidewalk cuts in an acceptable manner until repairs are complete. If the permittee does not make the required repairs in the time stipulated, or does not maintain the area prior to replacement in an acceptable manner, then the Town's personnel will maintain and/or repair such cuts and invoice the permittee for actual costs plus fifty percent (50%). 
(d)  Safety. The permittee shall furnish the necessary flagmen, directional signs, and barricades for safety and traffic control during construction. 
(e)  Inspection. The Public Services Director, through the Street Superintendent or his authorized agent, shall have the authority to inspect any construction undertaken under this section at any time to determine proper compliance with Town standards. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-59. - Installation costs. 
    All pipe and concrete or other material used in the construction of entrances to private driveways shall be paid for by the applicant or property owner. Where the Town is installing curb and gutter on a street, the cost of the driveway shall be included in the assessment. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-60. - Manual of procedures and specifications. 
    Driveway construction and curb cuts and removals shall be subject to the procedures and specifications contained in the Design and Construction Specifications manual as issued by the Town. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Secs. 16-61-16-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EXISTING STREETS IMPROVEMENT POLICY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-76. - Scope. 
    Street and local improvements including paving, repairing, widening and installation of curb and gutter shall be made and the expenses thereof defrayed as provided in this article, except as may be otherwise provided by the Charter of the Town. This policy shall apply only to existing public streets dedicated and accepted for public use. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-77. - Applicability. 
    If the Board of Aldermen shall, after consideration of any petition, determine that the street improvements referred to in such petition shall be made in accordance with the petition, then the policy as set out in this article shall be applicable. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-78. - Petition. 
    A petition shall be submitted requesting street and local improvements signed by at least a majority of landowners who shall represent at least a majority of all the lineal feet of frontage of the land abutting upon the street or streets or part thereof proposed to be improved. The petition shall be in compliance with the North Carolina General Statutes and shall be filed with the Town Clerk who shall investigate the sufficiency thereof and shall submit the petition to the Board of Aldermen who shall consider and act upon it after the Town Clerk has investigated the sufficiency of the petition. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-79. - Resurfacing paved street. 
    Whenever it shall become necessary to resurface a street that has been paved as provided in this article, the Town will do the work at its own expense without any cost to the property owners. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Secs. 16-80-16-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COSTS 

Sec. 16-91. - Schedule. 
    The current cost per front foot to be assessed to abutting property for paving, curb, and guttering shall be maintained by the Town Clerk in the Schedule of Fees and Charges of the Town of Kernersville as set forth in section 1-9. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014; Ord. No. O-2014-33, § 6, 12-2-2014) 
Sec. 16-92. - Grading, subgrade. 
    The Town will pay the entire cost of grading and preparing the subgrade for all paving and curb and gutter any particular project approved by the Board of Aldermen without any cost to the abutting property. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-93. - Unpaved streets, new curbs, gutters. 
    Where a street has not been paved or curb and gutter installed the entire cost of all paving and the cost of the construction of all curbs and gutters deemed necessary by the Town shall be charged at an equal rate against and paid by the property owners and assessed upon the lots and parcels of land abutting directly on the improvements according to the extent of their respective frontage and in such proportion of such cost as specified in the petition; provided however, that the Town will pay the cost of paving intersections. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-94. - Paved streets. 
    Where a street has been paved and the Town is petitioned to widen the street and install curb and gutter, the abutting property owners shall receive fifty percent (50%) credit on the cost of paving or resurfacing such street. The entire cost of the construction of all curbs and gutters shall be charged against and paid by the abutting property owners on said street. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-95. - Utility service. 
    If it shall be necessary or advisable for sewer and water service to be made from the mains in the street to the property lines before the pavement is constructed, the improvements will be made by the Town and/or the Winston-Salem/Forsyth County Utilities Division and the cost shall be included in the assessment to respective owners. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-96. - Driveways. 
(a)  The property owner will pay for the construction, grading or paving of any new driveway that may be constructed at his property. 
(b)  All existing driveways shall be replaced as near as possible to the original construction at the Town's expense. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 16-97. - Collection. 
    If the petition is accepted and the improvement is made by the Town, then the Town will levy an assessment against that property and proceed to collect the cost according to law. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Secs. 16-98-16-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RESERVED 

Secs. 16-111-16-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SELLING ON STREETS OR SIDEWALKS PROHIBITED 

Sec. 16-151. - Selling on streets or sidewalks prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  Except during special community events as specifically authorized herein or during the Spring Folly as authorized in chapter 5, it shall be unlawful to display, store, sell or offer for sale any goods, wares, merchandise or any other tangible items on any street, sidewalk or public right of way within the Town. Goods, wares and merchandise shall include but not be limited to fruits, vegetables, farm products, dairy products, fish, game, poultry, meat, plants, flowers, appliances, wearing apparel, jewelry, art work, cosmetics and beauty aids, health products, medicines, household products or furnishings, and food, confections or drinks of any kind, whether or not for immediate consumption. Sidewalk means all that area legally open to public use as a pedestrian public way between the curb line and the legal building line of the abutting property. 
(b)  (1)  The Board of Aldermen shall have the authority to authorize special events during which certain streets designated in said authorization may be closed and certain public areas, parks and sidewalks designated in said authorization may be utilized for the special event. All such special events shall be sponsored or co-sponsored by the Town. The Town may designate a nonprofit organization as the agency to conduct such special events. In the event a nonprofit organization is so designated, then said organization shall be responsible for the administration and control of the event and only those participants specifically authorized by the designated organization shall be entitled to participate in the special event without the restrictions imposed by this article. A nonprofit organization conducting such a special event may be designated as the Town Manager's designee for the purpose of issuing vendor permits as required by Article IV of Chapter 5 of this Code. 
(2)  No sale of any goods, wares or merchandise as defined herein shall be permitted within the area designated for the special event except as authorized by the designated organization and subject to the reasonable controls adopted by said organization or the Town. The designated organization may request and the Board of Aldermen may permit a charge to vendors of a fee for the right to participate in the special event. All vendors shall be required to procure a permit for peddling as required by Article IV of Chapter 5 of this Code. 
(3)  Any vendor or peddler at any special event who sells food or food products subject to the regulation of the Forsyth County Health Department shall comply with any and all applicable regulations of the Forsyth County Health Department. 
(4)  Special community events shall be designated by the Board of Aldermen by resolution and the resolution shall include the following information: 
a.  Dates, times and the location for the special event. 
b.  Designation of nonprofit organization administering and controlling the event, if applicable. 
c.  Activities that will be authorized on the public streets areas, and rights-of-way. 
(5)  Nothing herein shall in any way prohibit or restrict any legally operated business located within or adjacent to the special event area from operating its business on its property in its customary fashion. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-02, 1-7-2014) 
Chapter 17 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2012-07, adopted April 3, 2012, amended ch. 17, §§ 17-1-17-21, to read as set out herein. Prior to its adoption ch. 17 pertained to similar subject matter and was derived from Ord. No. O-2002-15, adopted May 7, 2002 and Ord. No. O-2002-25, adopted July 2, 2002. 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 9; streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 16. 

Sec. 17-1 - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Chief: the Chief of Police of the Town of Kernersville and his or her designee(s). 
    Driver: any person who actually drives a taxicab on the streets of the town for hire. "Drive" or "driving a taxicab" means driving a taxicab for hire on such streets. 
    Driver's permit: the license, issued by the Chief, under which a person may drive a taxicab for hire. 
    Franchise: authorization granted by the Board of Aldermen to operate and maintain a taxi service within the town. 
    Owner: any person who owns one (1) or more taxicabs or who engages in the operation of one (1) or more taxicabs under a trade or service name. (Individual/business who has been granted a franchise). 
    Proof of financial responsibility: a certificate of any insurance carrier duly authorized to do business in the State of North Carolina certifying that there is in effect a policy of liability insurance insuring the owner and driver of the taxicab, his or her agents and employees, while in the performance of their duties, against loss from any liability imposed by law for damages including damages for care and loss of services because of bodily injury to or death of any person and injury to or destruction of property caused by accident and arising out of the ownership, use or operation, including driving, of such taxicab or taxicabs in the limits required by state law (G.S. § 20-280(b)), as amended from time to time. 
    Taxicab: a passenger motor vehicle plying for hire for which public patronage is accepted or solicited and which is so designed as to seat comfortably not more than nine (9) persons but shall not include motor vehicles or motor vehicle carriers as defined in G.S. Ch. 20, Art. 17. 
    Taximeter: a mechanical device which is installed in a taxicab for the purpose of computing the fare for a trip upon the basis of distance traveled, waiting time, or both. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-2 - Purpose. 
    For the better protection of the public interest, health, safety, welfare or convenience, the following rules and regulations are hereby adopted setting forth the conditions, requirements and limitations under which an owner may operate a taxi service and engage in the business of providing taxi service within the town. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-3. - Compliance with chapter. 
    Unlawful operation or driving of taxicabs. It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of operating one (1) or more taxicabs, or to drive any taxicab within the corporate limits of the town or within one (1) mile beyond the corporate limits in every direction, unless such person shall have complied, and shall continue to comply, with the provisions of this chapter. Notwithstanding the preceding, taxicab drivers and operators who are duly licensed in another jurisdiction may come into the town to pick up or deliver persons if their services were requested by the passenger, provided they do not solicit fares within town limits. The term "solicit fares" shall include directing advertisement of their services toward town residents, such as advertising in the town phone directory. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-4. - Proof of financial responsibility. 
    The owner and driver of every taxicab shall furnish and keep in effect for each taxicab proof of financial responsibility. The insurance policy shall contain a clause obligating the insurance company to give fifteen (15) days' written notice to the Town prior to the cancellation of coverage or reduction in coverage or other material change in the policy of such insurance on any taxicab. The operating permit for any taxicab shall be automatically revoked upon the lapse, cancellation or termination of the insurance on that vehicle unless the same has been renewed or replaced and a new certificate filed with the Town. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-5. - General prohibited practices. 
    Prohibited practices. In addition to the practices prohibited elsewhere in this chapter, it shall be unlawful: 
(1)  Illegal rates. For a driver to charge or attempt to charge a passenger a greater rate of fare than that which is posted in the vehicle as required by this chapter. 
(2)  Deviating from direct route. For a driver to fail, refuse or neglect to proceed with all reasonable dispatch by the nearest practicable route to the destination of the first person applying to him for transportation unless the person has granted permission to take on or wait for additional passengers. 
(3)  Illegal use of a cab. For a driver, on or off duty, to knowingly permit a taxicab to be used for any illegal act listed in G.S. Arts. 26 and 27 (G.S. §§ 14A-177 et. seq., 14A-203 et. seq.) or to transport any person in a taxicab to any place used for such purposes, or to acquire and transport in a taxicab any alcoholic beverage for another, or to transport any person to any place where alcoholic beverages or drugs are illegally dispensed or stored. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-6. - Rates and charges. 
    The Board of Aldermen shall have the continued right to fix and establish the maximum fares and rates to be paid by the passengers in the area referred to in any franchise granted, commensurate with the best interest of the citizens of the town. All maximum rates and charges shall be established by resolution of the Board of Aldermen and modified as deemed appropriated by the Board. 
    A sign setting forth these maximum rates shall be posted inside the taxicab at a conspicuous place where it will be visible to passengers. The driver of the taxicab shall not reset the taximeter until the fare is paid. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-7. - Hours of operation. 
    The Board of Aldermen shall establish by a franchise ordinance the minimal hours of operation and the same shall be set forth in a schedule as follows: Minimum Hours of Operation [2] 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- (Per city-Hours of operation will be set in each individual franchise contract.) 

Sec. 17-8. - Taxi-stand designation. 
    The Board of Aldermen may from time to time designate stands for taxicabs throughout the Town. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-9. - Indemnification of Town. 
    All taxi franchisees shall indemnify and save harmless the Kernersville Police Department, and the Town of Kernersville, its officers, and its employees from and against any and all claims, demands, actions, suits, and proceedings by others, and against all liability to others arising out of the exercise or enjoyment of its franchise. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-10. - Taxi franchise. 
    No person shall engage in or otherwise participate in the operation of any taxi service within the town unless such person shall have first obtained and shall hold a currently valid franchise granted pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
    The Board of Aldermen by ordinance may, in its discretion, limit the total number of taxicab franchises to be granted. 
    The Town Manager or his designee shall oversee administration of this chapter together with all taxi franchises including applications, investigations, vehicle inspections, permits, monitoring and enforcement associated with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-11. - Application for taxi franchise. 
(a)  Any person seeking issuance of a taxi franchise shall file a written application to the Town on a form supplied by the Town. Submission of any false or misleading information to obtain or renew a franchise shall be grounds for denial, suspension or revocation of a franchise. 
The Town Manager or his designee will conduct an investigation to determine applicant's qualifications. Submission of an application for a taxi franchise shall constitute a waiver of any privileges and rights of privacy with respect to any document in existence reasonably related to the determination of the applicant's qualifications and shall serve as an authorization to the Town Manager to make inquiry of any person or entity, and to receive any oral or written reports from any person or entity, regarding any facts, evidence or information reasonably related to the determination of the applicant's qualifications. If needed, the applicant shall sign a separate written authorization for the release of documents or information concerning the applicant. 
(b)  No taxi franchise will be issued unless the applicant meets the following requirements: 
(1)  Is at least eighteen (18) years of age or is otherwise legally emancipated and is a U.S. citizen or possesses documentation of eligibility to work in the United States; 
(2)  Has not has been convicted of any of the following: 
a.  Any felony against the state or any offense against another state which would have been a felony if committed in North Carolina; 
b.  Any federal or state law relating to the use, possession, or sale of alcoholic beverages or narcotic or barbiturate drugs; 
c.  Any federal or state law relating to prostitution; 
d.  Habitual violation of traffic laws or ordinances. 
(3)  Is not a habitual user of, or addicted to, narcotic or barbiturate drugs or intoxicating liquors; 
(4)  Has not had any franchise issued under this chapter revoked within the twenty-four (24) months preceding the application. 
(c)  If at any time the franchisee is criminally charged with any traffic or criminal violation, the franchisee shall notify the Town within ten (10) days of such violations. 
(d)  An application shall include the following: 
(1)  List of all motor vehicles that applicant proposes to use in the taxi service. 
(2)  List of all drivers whom applicant proposes to use in the taxi service. 
(e)  All applications shall be submitted to the Town with an application fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-12. - Award/denial of franchise. 
    The Town Manager, upon completion of a franchise investigation, shall make a report with recommendations to the Board of Aldermen regarding approval or denial of a franchise or franchise renewal based on an investigation. 
    If approved, the Board of Aldermen shall by ordinance authorize the Town to enter into a franchise agreement with owner to be executed on behalf of the Town by the Mayor and attested to by the Town Clerk. If denied, the town will notify the owner in writing of its franchise denial. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-13. - Acceptance. 
    Within thirty (30) days after the town has taken final action to approve the granting of a franchise, the owner shall file a written acceptance of the franchise, acknowledged before a notary public, with the Town Clerk. Such acceptance shall acknowledge that the owner agrees to be bound by and to comply with the provisions of this chapter, franchise, or any resolution that would apply to vehicles for hire ordinance. The written acceptance shall be in such form and content as is satisfactory to and approved by the Town Attorney. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-14. - Expiration and renewal. 
    A franchise shall be nonexclusive and shall be granted for a term of three years from effective date of the franchise. The franchise may be renewed for terms of three (3) years. 
    The franchise shall not be sold, transferred, leased, assigned, or disposed of, in whole or in part, either by voluntary, involuntary, or forced sale, or by merger or consolidation or otherwise. 
    If the franchisee, for any reason, is no longer able to provide the taxi service as applied for, the taxi franchise shall immediately terminate. 
    Renewal requests must be forwarded to the Town at least thirty (30) days prior to franchise expiration. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-14.1 - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The Board of Aldermen may suspend or revoke any franchise previously granted upon a showing that the franchise has not been operated or maintained in accordance with the Town of Kernersville Taxi Franchise Ordinance. The Town shall notify the franchisee in writing that a franchise is suspended or revoked. The franchisee has ten (10) days from the receipt of such notice to appeal the determination. Appeal will be filed with Town Manager. The Board of Aldermen shall conduct a hearing on the suspension and shall have final authority on suspension or revocation. Upon temporary suspension or revocation, the franchise owner will immediately suspend operations allowed by franchise until final determination after the appeal. 
(b)  Suspension or revocation can be based on any violation of this chapter, including, but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Failure to operate the vehicle(s) permitted in the franchise. 
(2)  Failure to maintain the vehicles in good order and repair. 
(3)  Failure to maintain the required insurance. 
(4)  Failure to pay taxes due to the Town for the vehicles or their operation. 
(5)  Repeated and persistent violation of traffic ordinances by drivers. 
(6)  Failure to report any accident involving one of the taxis. 
(7)  Willful failure to comply with the requirements of this chapter. 
(8)  Unauthorized transfer of a driver permit or use of a vehicle not reported in accordance with this chapter. 
(9)  Failure to properly register the taxis with the State of North Carolina. 
(10)  Conviction of the owner of a felony, a federal or state statute or municipal ordinance related to possession or sale of intoxicating liquors, a federal or state statute related to sexual offenses, a federal or state statute related to illegal drugs, or repeated violation of traffic laws or ordinances, or habitual use by the franchisee of illegal drugs or intoxicating liquors, or violation by the franchisee of any federal or state statute relating to the illegal use of a firearm. 
(11)  Permitting any person convicted of the crimes listed in subsection (10) to operate a taxi unless the conviction is reviewed by the Chief of Police or his designee and consent given for that driver. 
(12)  False or misleading statements in the application for franchise. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-15. - Annual fee. 
    A franchisee shall pay to the town an annual fee in an amount as set from time to time by the Board of Aldermen in its annual budget, said fees to be set in the Schedule of Fees and Charges adopted in conjunction with the annual budget ordinance. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-16. - Taxi approval. 
    The Town shall have the right to inspect, approve or disapprove the various taxicabs and all equipment thereon operated in connection with the franchisee's taxi business. All vehicles must also pass the annual safety inspection required by the North Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles and be maintained in a manner that would meet the requirements established by that inspection. The Town Manager or his designee shall have the right to order removal from service of any vehicle deemed to be a safety hazard. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-17. - Identification of taxis. 
    All taxicabs will display appropriate taxi identification. Taxi identification will consist of the following: 
(1)  Letters/numbers will be placed on both sides of taxi; 
(2)  Letters/numbers will not be less than three inches in height; 
(3)  The color to be used for lettering and numbers shall be of sharp contrast to background so as to be easily visible at a reasonable distance, especially at night time with street lights. 
(4)  Franchise trade name; 
(5)  Taxicab number; 
(6)  Telephone number. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-18. - Taxi driver permits. 
(a)  No person shall operate any taxicab without first having obtained a taxi driver permit issued by the Town. Subsequent to the granting of a taxi franchise, any proposed driver shall submit a signed, notarized application for driver permit on a form provided by the Town. Submission of false or misleading information to obtain or renew a driver's permit shall be grounds for denial, suspension or revocation of driver permit. 
(b)  Prior to the driver's permit being issued by the Chief of Police or his or her designee, the applicant shall sign a form consenting to the use of the applicant's name, race, sex, date of birth, social security number and fingerprints for the purpose of conducting a state criminal history records check through the North Carolina Department of Justice utilizing the DCI (Division of Criminal Information) Network or submitting a national criminal history records check through the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The Chief of Police, or his or her designee, shall submit the driver's fingerprints and identifying information to the North Carolina Department of Justice for a thorough state criminal records check and for submission to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for thorough national criminal records check. 
(c)  In addition to the local application fee established herein below, the driver's permit applicant shall pay a Criminal History Record check fee in the amount established by the State of North Carolina and the Federal Bureau of Investigation for such record checks. The Criminal History Record check fee shall be transferred by the Town of Kernersville to the North Carolina Department of Justice and Federal Bureau of Investigation to conduct the record check. 
(d)  Criminal History Records information obtained from the North Carolina Department of Justice or the Federal Bureau of Investigation shall be privileged information and shall be kept confidential. This information shall only be disseminated to the Chief of Police or his or her designee and the Kernersville Town Manager to the extent necessary to indicate approval or denial of a taxi driver's permit. This information shall not be public information as defined by Chapter 132 of the North Carolina General Statutes. 
(e)  Authority to conduct a State and Federal Criminal History Record Check is authorized pursuant to North Carolina General Statute 160A-304. 
(f)  Prior to the denial or termination of a license or driver's permit based upon Criminal History Record Information the Chief of Police or his or her designee shall verify the existence of a record by either obtaining a certified public record or by submitting a fingerprint card of the individual to the North Carolina Department of Justice for verification that the Criminal History Record Information belongs to the individual. 
(g)  At the time of submission of a driver application, a non-reimbursable fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) must be submitted. The Town Manager or his designee shall be responsible for conducting an investigation to determine applicant's qualifications. Said application shall include an authorization by the applicant for the release by agencies or individuals of information related to the application. 
(h)  No driver's permit will be issued unless the applicant meets the following requirements: 
(1)  Is at least eighteen (18) years of age or is otherwise legally emancipated and is a U.S. citizen or possesses documentation of eligibility to work in the United States; 
(2)  Has not been convicted of any of the following: 
a.  Any felony against the state or any offense against another state which would have been a felony if committed in North Carolina; 
b.  Any federal or state law relating to the use, possession, or sale of alcoholic beverages or narcotic or barbiturate drugs; 
c.  Any federal or state law relating to prostitution; 
d.  Habitual violation of traffic laws or ordinances. 
(3)  Is not a habitual user of, or addicted to, narcotic or barbiturate drugs or intoxicating liquors; 
(4)  Has not had any permit issued under this chapter revoked within the twenty-four (24) months preceding the application. 
(i)  If approved, a taxi driver's permit will be issued by the Chief of Police. This driver's permit will serve as an identification of driver and show his/her authorization to drive a taxicab within a designated franchise. 
(j)  The driver's permit will be displayed in such a manner as to be in full view of all passengers at all times while the driver is on duty. The driver shall retain custody of the identification card, and present it, on demand, for inspection by any passenger or law enforcement officer. 
(k)  All drivers' permits shall be and remain the property of the Town. Loss, theft, destruction or defacement shall be immediately reported to the Chief of Police and a replacement permit obtained. 
(l)  Drivers' permits are not transferable from one person to another. 
(m)  If at any time driver is criminally charged with any traffic or criminal violation, the driver shall notify the Chief of Police within ten (10) days of these violations. 
(n)  Drivers' permits expire on December 31 of each year. Requests for renewal shall be made at least thirty (30) days prior to expiration date. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-19. - Taximeter. 
(a)  All taxicabs operated within the town shall be equipped with a functional taximeter that is visible at all times to the passenger. 
(b)  A franchisee must submit to the Town a certificate of calibration of each taximeter biennially. 
(c)  No person shall use or permit to be used upon any taxicab a taximeter that shall be in such condition as to be more than five (5) percent from accuracy. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-20. - Daily manifest. 
(a)  The franchisee shall require every driver to maintain a daily manifest upon which is recorded every trip, showing the place of origin and destination of each trip, the amount of fare, the number of passengers, time in and time out, and shall record each trip immediately after such trip is completed. All such manifests shall be returned to the franchisee by the driver at the conclusion of his daily tour of duty. The forms for such records shall be furnished to the driver by the franchisee and shall be of a character either approved or furnished by the Town. These records shall be maintained for inspection by the Town. 
(b)  Every franchisee shall retain and preserve all drivers' manifests in a safe place for at least ninety (90) days. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 17-21. - Vehicle operation pursuant to contract. 
(a)  Any vehicle for hire may be operated by the owner or his duly authorized agent, employee or lessee. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any provision in this chapter to the contrary, a franchisee may enter into a contract or lease agreement with any driver whereby the franchisee leases a vehicle for hire to the driver for such fee as they may agree upon or where the driver owns the vehicle for hire and pays a fee to the franchisee for his furnishing the insurance required by this article, for the use of terminal facilities of the franchisee, for the privilege of operating under the certificate of the franchisee, or for any other privilege or service agreed upon by them. 
(c)  A franchisee may contract with another franchisee and pay a fee for telephone or dispatch services. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall alter the requirement that each driver and each franchisee must procure the necessary authorization from the Town in order to operate in the Town. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-07, § 1, 4-3-2012)
